prompt.p: A 44-year-old type 1 diabetic is admitted for an elective right hemicolectomy for suspected cancer the evening before surgery. She normally takes Novorapid 10â€“12 U t.i.d. with glargine 18 U nocte and is on no other medication. She is otherwise well and first on the list for the morning so will be starved from 2 am.
What is the most appropriate management of her diabetes peri-operatively while she is fasting?

choiceInteraction.simpleChoice: Allow to eat until goes to theatre
Give reduced dose of insulin in the morning
Give usual dose of insulin in the morning
Omit insulin until returns from theatre
Start sliding scale insulin from 2 am

modalFeedback.p: Option E is Correct. This is the most appropriate step. Careful peri-operative glycaemic control has been shown to improve outcomes.
Option A is Incorrect. She should be starved for 6 hours preoperatively due to the risk of aspiration at induction of anaesthesia.
Option B is Incorrect. Even with a reduced dose there is a significant risk of hypoglycaemia given the period of starvation.
Option C is Incorrect. Without a source of carbohydrate there is the significant risk of hypoglycaemia with this strategy.

Option D is Incorrect. There is a risk of ketoacidosis with this strategy. While omitting insulin and careful monitoring of blood sugars may be reasonable for more minor procedures this is not appropriate for major abdominal surgery.
